title: What is your advice for someone attending boarding school? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m a current senior at Phillips Exeter Academy. I’m not sure if these pieces of advice would be relevant across the range of boarding schools, but this is the advice that I would give to someone coming into Exeter. Hopefully you could use it wherever you end up. Firstly, go to club night. At Exeter, there’s a club night one of the first weekends of fall term. If you miss that, it’s tough to know who to contact if you want to join clubs in the future, especially if you’re new. I missed club night and it took me a week and a half to track down the names and emails of the co-heads of the clubs I wanted to join. Clubs are essential for not being bored out of your mind on the weekend and having several circles of friends with similar interests. Also, sign up for 15 clubs. Go to a bunch of first meetings, and then choose 3–4 that you want to dedicate your time too. Who knows, you might uncover a secret passion of yours. Secondly, go to the meet and greets. Exeter has several meet and greets for new studentsThey are essential for getting an initial group of acquaintances. When you’re new, boarding school can be daunting. You’ve got your roommate, the people in your dorm, and maybe the people in your classes or sports team. You might feel like you don’t know anyone… because you don’t. But that’s fine. Clubs will help with that, but meet and greets are essential to getting those first few friends that you can recognize and sit with at the dining hall. Thirdly, stay up late. Maybe even pull a few all-nighters. I’m serious. Learn how to stay up until 3 without falling asleep. Consistently. Obviously you shouldn’t do it during the school week. You should go to bed at a decent time Monday-Thursday. Be healthy. But the weekend? You’re free. Some of the greatest memories in my years of Exeter have been staying up untill 5:00 am on a Saturday morning with my best friends and then running to mcdonalds in the snow. Those are the moments that will make your time at boarding school worth it. Fourthly, on a more serious note, don’t be afraid to go to people and ask for help. Boarding school can be tough. There will be times that you’ll be stressed out, homesick, heartbroken, and depressed. It happens. It’s high school. And if you don’t have your family or friends from home to support you, it can be very difficult. Although going to a teacher or counselor might be intimidating, it’s vital to find a friend to go to in times of need. It could be your roommate or someone in your dorm or someone on your sports team, but whoever it is, it’s crucial that you find a crutch to lean on. What’s comforting is that they’re most likely suffering from the same stuff that you might be dealing with, so you and that close friend could help each other through the tough times of a boarding school life. Boarding school was the greatest decision of my life so far. Whether it’s building a six-foot tall snowman in the dead of winter or losing our dorm stove privileges because we burnt some ramen and caused a fire alarm at 2 am on a school night, I’ll carry with me those friendships and memories for the rest of my life. You’re about to engage in a fantastic adventure. You’re going to grow so much and learn so much, so live in the moment, make some great friendships, join some great clubs and learn learn learn learn. These are the days that we’re both going to look back on and say, “Those were the good old days.” Don’t let them slip away. Good Luck.

I think the best suggestion is to keep being you! I started attending a boarding school at the age of 16. At first, I had problems fitting in. The most popular people treat people most badly. Without parents constraining them (In most cases without knowing their behaviors at school), the students gain popularity by drinking alcohol and taking drugs. I’ve seen some people changed. In order to fit in. they buy replica shoes and puke (because of alcohol) as much as they can as if it is the only criterion to integrate into this society. But eventually, they’ll get nothing except falling notes and bad reputations. I’ve also got to know some interesting people in the school, though they are not the so-called mainstream, I had a happy time with them!

These 5 things: 1. Be grateful. Many students wish they had the resources to be at a boarding school. It is an impossibility for most. You are lucky. Remember that. 2. Remember that you become like the 5 people with whom you spend most of your time. Choose wisely. 3. Keep in touch with your family and share your ups and downs as often as possible. Don’t isolate yourself; they love you. Keep in touch with school counselors, too. The academic pressure is very real; don’t be self-conscious about having a regular sit-down with professionals at the school in order to decompress. 4. Get involved. Find your people - the other students with whom you have things in common. Join stuff. Look into the faces of the other students and smile and say hello each day. 5. Have fun. These should be the best years of your life. Don’t miss chances to make memories, so take those weekend trips!

Boarding school. $65,000 per year or more. Rich and powerful parents and the children of those parents. If you fit that mold, then act responsibly and be a glowing beacon for a good Person. If you are a scholarship and financial aid student there, then do Not get sucked into the morass of bad behavior that might be forgiven because the headmaster knows your wealthy/powerful parents. Yours aren’t and the other parents will have the headmaster Sacrifice You to save their precious children. Be wary. Be Very Wary.

My advice comes from the six years I spent at The Linsly School, a boarding school in West Virginia. I think my experience was pretty typical for a day student (I lived in Wheeling and did not board at the school). Having said that, my advice is this: do everything! Obviously, you can’t do everything but you can do a lot! Clubs, sports, organizations — boarding school gives you the unique opportunity to explore a tremendous range of interests that can help guide you in your next steps in life, especially if you’re going to college.

First and foremost you must know the location of the boarding school that you intending to go to,location could also mean the distance to be covered.Know also if the boarding school has specialised teachers cos I have noticed with dismay that going to boarding school is like an escape from Sobiba instead of leaning a lot involve themselves in illicit activities. Another thing would be,does the school produce good students at the end of the day ?I end here hop this helps someone.

Don’t hang out in your room all day, not socializing with people, I did that at my first boarding school but not at my second, and that was one of the major reasons why I enjoyed my second significantly more.
